meanings.definition: Quote or mention as evidence or support.
meanings.sent1: In my essay, I will cite the expert's opinion to back up my argument.
meanings.sent2: During the debate, the speaker cited several statistics to support her claims.
meanings.sent3: The detective decided to cite the suspect's alibi as evidence of his innocence.
meanings.sent4: The teacher always reminds us to cite our sources to avoid plagiarism.
meanings.sent5: She made sure to cite the relevant case law to strengthen her legal argument.

meanings.definition: Refer to (a passage, book, or author) as evidence for or justification of an argument or statement.
meanings.sent1: When discussing the topic, I will cite the famous author's work to support my view.
meanings.sent2: The historian often cites primary sources to provide credibility to his research.
meanings.sent3: I jokingly told my friend I would cite his words in my next academic paper.
meanings.sent4: The politician strategically cited historical events to make a compelling argument.
meanings.sent5: The student was asked to cite specific examples from the text to prove her point.

meanings.definition: Summon (someone) to appear in a court of law.
meanings.sent1: The judge may cite the witness to testify in the trial.
meanings.sent2: The lawyer decided to cite the defendant to appear in court next week.
meanings.sent3: The comedian joked that the judge might cite him for making bad puns.
meanings.sent4: The prosecutor cited the key witness to provide crucial testimony.
meanings.sent5: The police officer had to cite the suspect to appear in front of the judge.
